title: Spike Lee criticizes James Dolan while wearing Charles Oakley jersey
text:
NBA  24pm  24pm EST Basketball, NBA, News, New York Knicks, English The Knicks superfan was decked out in a No. 34 jersey Sunday to show his support for Oakley in a back-and-forth feud with owner James Dolan. Spike Lee (Getty Images) 
Updated at 7:24  24 p.m. ET 
Knicks superfan Spike Lee was decked out in a Charles Oakley No. 34 jersey Sunday as he watched from his familiar courtside seat while his favorite team, mired in controversy, earned a 94-90 win over the Spurs at Madison Square Garden. 
It was a topical display for the famed filmmaker, a lifetime Knicks fan, who said he had the jersey made to show support for Oakley in his back-and-forth with owner James Dolan and expressed disbelief over how the Knicks were treating a former star. 
MORE: 14 worst choke-jobs in NBA playoff history 
"I mean, how can you say somebody is an alcoholic? You just can't, in my opinion," Lee told reporters, via ESPN.com . "And even if the person was, why would you say that? I don't know why you would say that. All I can do is wear my jersey." 
Lee was speaking to reporters inside the tunnel where Oakley had been ejected from the Garden and arrested four days earlier following a scuffle with security. 
The Knicks have engaged in bizarre back-and-forth finger pointing with Oakley since his arrest, releasing a series of statements pleading for Oakley to "get some help soon" and painting him as the aggressor. Dolan insinuated Friday that Oakley is an alcoholic. 
"I'm sure he has problems," Dolan, a recovering addict himself, told the New York Post . "I didn't have the problem he has, but when you're fighting addiction, it's not that much different from anger management or other diseases where you can't control yourself." 
Oakley has denied these claims and maintained no wrongdoing before being ejected during Wednesday's game. 
Dolan banned Oakley from Madison Square Garden definitely. 
The Knicks' treatment of Oakley caused Lee to question the direction of the franchise. 
"Who's gonna come here?" he said, referring to potential free agents. 
"I'm not mad at any of the Knicks that showed up today," Lee said. "I stood up for everybody, gave them love. Applauded. I stood up for everybody. So I'm happy to see them. Under better conditions, yes. But I'm happy to see them regardless. But it just looks so obvious to me. â€¦I don't know, you got to ask the Garden. I'm just happy to see these guys.
